TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi serializable sealed beforefieldinit Color extends System.ValueType

Docs.summary: Represents an ARGB (alpha, red, green, blue) color.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Named colors are represented by using the properties of the Color structure. For more information about these colors, see [Colors by Name](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=92332).
The color of each pixel is represented as a 32-bit number: 8 bits each for alpha, red, green, and blue (ARGB). Each of the four components is a number from 0 through 255, with 0 representing no intensity and 255 representing full intensity. The alpha component specifies the transparency of the color: 0 is fully transparent, and 255 is fully opaque. To determine the alpha, red, green, or blue component of a color, use the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.A%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.R%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.G%2A>, or <xref:System.Drawing.Color.B%2A> property, respectively. You can create a custom color by using one of the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromArgb%2A> methods.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.A%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.R%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.G%2A>, and <xref:System.Drawing.Color.B%2A> properties of a Color, and the <xref:System.Drawing.Size.op_Implicit%2A> member.
This example is designed to be used with a Windows Form. Paste the code into the form and call the `ShowPropertiesOfSlateBlue` method from the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event-handling method, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.drawing.color_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.drawing.color_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.drawing.color_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets the alpha component value of this structure.
Docs.value: The alpha component value of this .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The color of each pixel is represented as a 32-bit number: 8 bits each for alpha, red, green, and blue (ARGB). The alpha component specifies the transparency of the color: 0 is fully transparent, and 255 is fully opaque. Likewise, an A value of 255 represents an opaque color. An A value from 1 through 254 represents a semitransparent color. The color becomes more opaque as A approaches 255.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the A, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.R%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.G%2A>, and <xref:System.Drawing.Color.B%2A> properties of a <xref:System.Drawing.Color>, and the <xref:System.Drawing.Size.op_Implicit%2A> member.
This example is designed to be used with a Windows Form. Paste the code into the form and call the `ShowPropertiesOfSlateBlue` method from the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event-handling method, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.drawing.color.a_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.drawing.color.a_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.drawing.color.a_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets the blue component value of this structure.
Docs.value: The blue component value of this .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The color of each pixel is represented as a 32-bit number: 8 bits each for alpha, red, green, and blue (ARGB). Each of the four components is a number from 0 through 255, with 0 representing no intensity and 255 representing full intensity. Likewise, B is a value from 0 to 255 with 0 representing no blue and 255 representing fully blue.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.A%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.R%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.G%2A>, and B properties of a <xref:System.Drawing.Color>, and the <xref:System.Drawing.Size.op_Implicit%2A> member.
This example is designed to be used with a Windows Form. Paste the code into the form and call the `ShowPropertiesOfSlateBlue` method from the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event-handling method, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.drawing.color.b_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.drawing.color.b_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.drawing.color.b_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly valuetype System.Drawing.Color Empty

Docs.summary: Represents a color that is .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance bool Equals(object obj) cil managed

Docs.summary: Tests whether the specified object is a structure and is equivalent to this structure.
Docs.returns: if is a structure equivalent to this structure; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This structure only does comparisons with other <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structures. To compare colors based solely on their ARGB values, you should use the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.ToArgb%2A> method. This is because the Equals and <xref:System.Drawing.Color.op_Equality%2A> members determine equivalency using more than just the ARGB value of the colors. For example, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.Black%2A> and `FromArgb(0,0,0)` are not considered equal, since <xref:System.Drawing.Color.Black%2A> is a named color and `FromArgb(0,0,0)` is not.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Drawing.Color FromArgb(int32 argb) cil managed

Docs.param: A value specifying the 32-bit ARGB value.
Docs.summary: Creates a structure from a 32-bit ARGB value.
Docs.returns: The structure that this method creates.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The byte-ordering of the 32-bit ARGB value is AARRGGBB. The most significant byte (MSB), represented by AA, is the alpha component value. The second, third, and fourth bytes, represented by RR, GG, and BB, respectively, are the color components red, green, and blue, respectively.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates three brushes, each a different color. Each <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure that is used to create a brush is created from a 32-bit ARGB value.
- Uses an imaginary triangle to position three circles.
- Paints three overlapping circles, each centered on one vertex of the triangle, using a different brush for each circle.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.f_3_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.f_3_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.f_3_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Drawing.Color FromArgb (int alpha, System.Drawing.Color baseColor);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Drawing.Color FromArgb(int32 alpha, valuetype System.Drawing.Color baseColor) cil managed

Docs.param: The alpha value for the new . Valid values are 0 through 255.
The from which to create the new .
Docs.summary: Creates a structure from the specified structure, but with the new specified alpha value. Although this method allows a 32-bit value to be passed for the alpha value, the value is limited to 8 bits.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To create an opaque color, set `alpha` to 255. To create a semitransparent color, set `alpha` to any value from 1 through 254.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
1. Creates <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structures from the three color component values (red, green, blue). Three <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structures are created, one for each primary color.
2. Iterates through a range of alpha values, changing the alpha value of a color.
3. During each iteration, sets the color of a brush to the modified color and paints a rectangle to show the color.
4. Repeats steps 2 and 3 for each primary color.
The alpha value is never fully opaque and the rectangles overlap so you get color-combination effects.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.f_2_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#2](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.f_2_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.f_2_1.vb)]

Docs.exception: is less than 0 or greater than 255.

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Drawing.Color FromArgb (int red, int green, int blue);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Drawing.Color FromArgb(int32 red, int32 green, int32 blue) cil managed

Docs.param: The red component value for the new . Valid values are 0 through 255.
The green component value for the new . Valid values are 0 through 255.
The blue component value for the new . Valid values are 0 through 255.
Docs.summary: Creates a structure from the specified 8-bit color values (red, green, and blue). The alpha value is implicitly 255 (fully opaque). Although this method allows a 32-bit value to be passed for each color component, the value of each component is limited to 8 bits.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
1. Creates <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structures from the three color component values (red, green, blue). Three <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structures are created, one for each primary color.
2. Iterates through a range of alpha values, changing the alpha value of a color.
3. During each iteration, sets the color of a brush to the modified color and paints a rectangle to show the color.
4. Repeats steps 2 and 3 for each primary color.
The alpha value is never fully opaque and the rectangles overlap so you get color-combination effects.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.f_0_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.f_0_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.f_0_1.vb)]

Docs.exception: , , or is less than 0 or greater than 255.

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Drawing.Color FromArgb (int alpha, int red, int green, int blue);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Drawing.Color FromArgb(int32 alpha, int32 red, int32 green, int32 blue) cil managed

Docs.param: The alpha component. Valid values are 0 through 255.
The red component. Valid values are 0 through 255.
The green component. Valid values are 0 through 255.
The blue component. Valid values are 0 through 255.
Docs.summary: Creates a structure from the four ARGB component (alpha, red, green, and blue) values. Although this method allows a 32-bit value to be passed for each component, the value of each component is limited to 8 bits.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To create an opaque color, set `alpha` to 255. To create a semitransparent color, set `alpha` to any value from 1 through 254.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates three brushes, each a different color. Each <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure that is used to create a brush is created from four component values (alpha, red, green, blue).
- Uses an imaginary triangle to position three circles.
- Paints three overlapping circles, each centered on one vertex of the triangle, using a different brush for each circle.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#4](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/61506e3b-cca7-461f-bf97-_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#4](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/61506e3b-cca7-461f-bf97-_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#4](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/61506e3b-cca7-461f-bf97-_1.vb)]

Docs.exception: , , , or is less than 0 or greater than 255.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Drawing.Color FromKnownColor(valuetype System.Drawing.KnownColor color) cil managed

Docs.summary: Creates a structure from the specified predefined color.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A predefined color is also called a known color and is represented by an element of the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates an instance of a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure, `redShade`, to be used for comparisons.
- Iterates through the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration elements to find all known colors that have the same brightness as `redShade`. The iterations are terminated when 15 matches are found or the value of the loop counter is greater than the last <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element.
- During each iteration, saves the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element—if it matches the criteria—in an array.
- Uses a brush to paint rectangles.
The first rectangle is painted the color represented by `redShade`. Each of the other rectangles is painted a <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> that matches the brightness of the `redShade`.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#5](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.f_4_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#5](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.f_4_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#5](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.f_4_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Drawing.Color FromName(string name) cil managed

Docs.param: A string that is the name of a predefined color. Valid names are the same as the names of the elements of the enumeration.
Docs.summary: Creates a structure from the specified name of a predefined color.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A predefined color is also called a known color and is represented by an element of the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration. If the `name` parameter is not the valid name of a predefined color, the FromName method creates a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure that has an ARGB value of 0 (that is, all ARGB components are 0).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.A%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.R%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.G%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.B%2A>, and FromName members of a <xref:System.Drawing.Color>, and the <xref:System.Drawing.Size.op_Implicit%2A> member.
This example is designed to be used with a Windows Form. Paste the code into the form and call the `ShowPropertiesOfSlateBlue` method from the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event-handling method, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.f_1_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.f_1_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.f_1_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets a system-defined color that has an ARGB value of `#FFFF00FF`.

remarks.format: ## Remarks For an example of this color, see [Colors by Name](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=92332).

Docs.summary: Gets the green component value of this structure.
Docs.value: The green component value of this .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The color of each pixel is represented as a 32-bit number: 8 bits each for alpha, red, green, and blue (ARGB). Each of the four components is a number from 0 through 255, with 0 representing no intensity and 255 representing full intensity. Likewise, G is a value from 0 to 255 with 0 representing no green and 255 representing fully green.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.A%2A>, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.R%2A>, G, and <xref:System.Drawing.Color.B%2A> properties of a <xref:System.Drawing.Color>, and the <xref:System.Drawing.Size.op_Implicit%2A> member.
This example is designed to be used with a Windows Form. Paste the code into the form and call the `ShowPropertiesOfSlateBlue` method from the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event-handling method, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.drawing.color.g_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.drawing.color.g_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.drawing.color.g_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets a system-defined color that has an ARGB value of `#FFDCDCDC`.

remarks.format: ## Remarks For an example of this color, see [Colors by Name](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=92332).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance float32 GetBrightness() cil managed

Docs.summary: Gets the hue-saturation-brightness (HSB) brightness value for this structure.
Docs.returns: The brightness of this . The brightness ranges from 0.0 through 1.0, where 0.0 represents black and 1.0 represents white.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates an instance of a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure, `redShade`, to be used for comparisons.
- Iterates through the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration elements to find all known colors that have the same brightness as `redShade`. The iterations are terminated when 15 matches are found or the value of the loop counter is greater than the last <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element.
- During each iteration, saves the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element—if it matches the criteria—in an array.
- Uses a brush to paint rectangles.
The first rectangle is painted the color represented by `redShade`. Each of the other rectangles is painted a <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> that matches the brightness of the `redShade`.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#6](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.g_0_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#6](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.g_0_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#6](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.g_0_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance int32 GetHashCode() cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns a hash code for this structure.
Docs.returns: An integer value that specifies the hash code for this .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance float32 GetHue() cil managed

Docs.summary: Gets the hue-saturation-brightness (HSB) hue value, in degrees, for this structure.
Docs.returns: The hue, in degrees, of this . The hue is measured in degrees, ranging from 0.0 through 360.0, in HSB color space.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates an instance of a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure, `redShade`, to be used for comparisons.
- Iterates through the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration elements to find all known colors that have the same hue as `redShade`. The iterations are terminated when 15 matches are found or the value of the loop counter is greater than the last <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element.
- During each iteration, saves the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element—if it matches the criteria—in an array.
- Uses a brush to paint rectangles.
The first rectangle is painted the color represented by `redShade`. Each of the other rectangles is painted a <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> that matches the hue of the `redShade`.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#7](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.g_1_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#7](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.g_1_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#7](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.g_1_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance float32 GetSaturation() cil managed

Docs.summary: Gets the hue-saturation-brightness (HSB) saturation value for this structure.
Docs.returns: The saturation of this . The saturation ranges from 0.0 through 1.0, where 0.0 is grayscale and 1.0 is the most saturated.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates an instance of a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure, `redShade`, to be used for comparisons.
- Iterates through the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration elements to find all known colors that have the same saturation as `redShade`. The iterations are terminated when 15 matches are found or the value of the loop counter is greater than the last <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element.
- During each iteration, saves the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element—if it matches the criteria—in an array.
- Uses a brush to paint rectangles.
The first rectangle is painted the color represented by `redShade`. Each of the other rectangles is painted a <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> that matches the saturation of the `redShade`.

Docs.summary: Specifies whether this structure is uninitialized.
Docs.value: This property returns if this color is uninitialized; otherwise, .

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this structure is a predefined color. Predefined colors are represented by the elements of the enumeration.
Docs.value: if this was created from a predefined color by using either the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromName%2A> method or the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromKnownColor%2A> method; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property does not do a comparison of the ARGB values. Therefore, when the IsKnownColor property is applied to a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure that is created by using the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromArgb%2A> method, IsKnownColor returns `false`, even if the ARGB value matches the ARGB value of a predefined color.

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this structure is a named color or a member of the enumeration.
Docs.value: if this was created by using either the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromName%2A> method or the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromKnownColor%2A> method; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property does not do a comparison of the ARGB values. Therefore, when the IsNamedColor property is applied to a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure that is created by using the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromArgb%2A> method, IsNamedColor returns `false`, even if the ARGB value matches the ARGB value of a predefined color.

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this structure is a system color. A system color is a color that is used in a Windows display element. System colors are represented by elements of the enumeration.
Docs.value: if this was created from a system color by using either the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromName%2A> method or the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromKnownColor%2A> method; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property does not do a comparison of the ARGB values. Therefore, when the IsSystemColor property is applied to a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure that is created by using the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromArgb%2A> method, IsSystemColor returns `false`, even if the ARGB value matches the ARGB value of a system color.

Docs.summary: Gets the name of this .

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method returns either the user-defined name of the color, if the color was created from a name, or the name of the known color. For custom colors, the RGB value is returned.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the Name property. This example is designed to be used with Windows Forms. Paste the code into a form that contains a button named `Button2` and associate the `Button2_Click` method with the button's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.Misc2#4](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.drawing.color.n_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.Misc2#4](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.drawing.color.n_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.Misc2#4](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.drawing.color.n_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool op_Equality (System.Drawing.Color left, System.Drawing.Color right);
.method public static hidebysig specialname bool op_Equality(valuetype System.Drawing.Color left, valuetype System.Drawing.Color right) cil managed

Docs.param: The that is to the left of the equality operator.
The that is to the right of the equality operator.
Docs.summary: Tests whether two specified structures are equivalent.
Docs.returns: if the two structures are equal; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method compares more than the ARGB values of the <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structures. It also does a comparison of some state flags. If you want to compare just the ARGB values of two <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structures, compare them using the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.ToArgb%2A> method.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the Equality operator and the <xref:System.Drawing.SystemColors> class. This example is designed to be used with a Windows Form that contains a button named `Button1`. Paste the following code into your form and associate the `Button1_Click` method with the button's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.CharacterRangeExample#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.o_0_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.CharacterRangeExample#2](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.o_0_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.CharacterRangeExample#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.o_0_1.vb)]

.method public static hidebysig specialname bool op_Inequality(valuetype System.Drawing.Color left, valuetype System.Drawing.Color right) cil managed

Docs.param: The that is to the left of the inequality operator.
The that is to the right of the inequality operator.
Docs.summary: Tests whether two specified structures are different.
Docs.returns: if the two structures are different; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method compares more than the ARGB values of the <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structures. It also does a comparison of some state flags. If you want to compare just the ARGB values of two <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structures, use the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.ToArgb%2A> method.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the Inequality operator and the <xref:System.Drawing.SystemColors> class. Docs.summary: Gets the red component value of this structure.
Docs.value: The red component value of this .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The color of each pixel is represented as a 32-bit number: 8 bits each for alpha, red, green, and blue (ARGB). Each of the four components is a number from 0 through 255, with 0 representing no intensity and 255 representing full intensity. Likewise,
R is a value from 0 to 255 with 0 representing no red and 255 representing fully red.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.A%2A>, R, <xref:System.Drawing.Color.G%2A>, and <xref:System.Drawing.Color.B%2A> properties of a <xref:System.Drawing.Color>, and the <xref:System.Drawing.Size.op_Implicit%2A> member.
This example is designed to be used with a Windows Form. Paste the code into the form and call the `ShowPropertiesOfSlateBlue` method from the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event-handling method, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.drawing.color.r_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.drawing.color.r_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.PointsAndSizes#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.drawing.color.r_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance int32 ToArgb() cil managed

Docs.summary: Gets the 32-bit ARGB value of this structure.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The byte-ordering of the 32-bit ARGB value is AARRGGBB. The most significant byte (MSB), represented by AA, is the alpha component value. The second, third, and fourth bytes, represented by RR, GG, and BB, respectively, are the color components red, green, and blue, respectively
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Iterates through the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration elements to find all known colors that have a non-zero green component and a zero-value red component, and that are not system colors.
- During each iteration, saves the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element—if it matches the criteria—in an array.
- Uses a brush to paint rectangles.
Each of the rectangles is painted a <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> that matches the criteria stated in the first bullet. The name of the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> and its component values are also displayed.
This example displays certain known colors, the names of the colors, and their four component values. The ToArgb method is used as a preliminary step to display the component values.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#9](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.t_0_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#9](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.t_0_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#9](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.t_0_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance valuetype System.Drawing.KnownColor ToKnownColor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Gets the value of this structure.
Docs.returns: An element of the enumeration, if the is created from a predefined color by using either the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromName%2A> method or the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromKnownColor%2A> method; otherwise, 0.

remarks.format: ## Remarks A predefined color is also called a known color and is represented by an element of the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration. When the ToKnownColor method is applied to a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure that is created by using the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromArgb%2A> method, ToKnownColor returns 0, even if the ARGB value matches the ARGB value of a predefined color. ToKnownColor also returns 0 when it is applied to a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure that is created by using the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromName%2A> method with a string name that is not valid.

Docs.summary: Gets a system-defined color that has an ARGB value of `#FFFF6347`.

remarks.format: ## Remarks For an example of this color, see [Colors by Name](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=92332).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance string ToString() cil managed

Docs.summary: Converts this structure to a human-readable string.
Docs.returns: A string that is the name of this , if the is created from a predefined color by using either the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromName%2A> method or the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromKnownColor%2A> method; otherwise, a string that consists of the ARGB component names and their values.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A predefined color is also called a known color and is represented by an element of the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration. When the ToString method is applied to a <xref:System.Drawing.Color> structure that is created by using the <xref:System.Drawing.Color.FromArgb%2A> method, ToString returns a string that consists of the ARGB component names and their values, even if the ARGB value matches the ARGB value of a predefined color.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event handler. The code performs the following actions:
- Iterates through the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> enumeration elements to find all known colors that have a non-zero green component and a zero-value red component and that are not system colors.
- During each iteration, saves the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> element—if it matches the criteria—in an array.
- Uses a brush to paint rectangles. Each of the rectangles is painted a <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> that matches the criteria stated in the first step. The name of the <xref:System.Drawing.KnownColor> and its component values are also displayed.
This example displays certain known colors and uses ToString to display the names of the colors and their four component values.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#10](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.color.t_1_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#10](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.color.t_1_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicColorExamples#10](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.color.t_1_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets a system-defined color.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the Transparent property. This example is designed to be used with Windows Forms. Paste the code into a form that contains two buttons named `Button1` and `Button2`. Call the `UseTransparentProperty` method in the form's constructor.
